channel.title: Windows Virtualization Options?
channel.description:
I have to run an instance of Windows Server 2008 on a Linux server to serve as an Active Directory domain controller. So it's going to need to have pretty high performance, at least with the network and hard drive access, but other than that I shouldn't need anything like direct hardware access or the like, I'll probably access it with rdesktop or similar.
Anyway, as far as I know, my options are virtualbox, Xen, and vmware. Do I have other options? Which do you guys think would be the best and why?

item.dc:creator: @Wizzup Wizzup?
item.description:
@Wizzup wrote:

[quote=“Mopman, post:8, topic:398180”]wtf @ “xen is a hack”

if anything, qemu is the “hack”[/quote]

Well, I am doing my thesis on jailing and confinement methods. I’ve read the main Xen paper (and KVM, etc) as well as some other papers on it; my best way to describe it in one sentence, is a hack - if my memory serves me well that is. Not a particularly nasty one and it seems to work pretty well, but a hack regardless.

Mopar, Samba sounds a lot easier to administer for sure. I didn’t know F-Secure, but I haven’t really used any virus checker in a long time now. I remember clamav served me well.

item.title: Windows Virtualization Options?
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Running windows under Xen looks like a bit of a hack. Also, I’m assuming he said that because they don’t seem to be pushing very hard to get it into the kernel, where as KVM is all in the kernel.

Anyway, I ended up going with KVM and testing out an install of Windows Server 2008 R2 in it, the virtualization worked well enough, but the Windows 2008 was so ridiculous to set up, and way too pricey to end up buying, so I went with Samba for a file server (and login server soon), and wpkg for remotely keeping software installed and up to date. For an anti-virus I went with F-secure, as it can run on and be managed centrally from the Linux server. A combination of rsync and SpiderOak do the backups. The setup is working great so far.

item.title: Windows Virtualization Options?
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

You also have KVM, but I would go with Xen simply because of it’s interoperability with eucalyptus in case you ever wanted to set up a small multi-computer based computer to expand it.

I used to use VMWare on a Windows machine to run a newer version of Windows, Mac, and some distros of Linux. The quality really wasn’t great, but that was because the original Windows was sucking all my resources.

I’m currently experimenting with a small Xen / Eucalyptus setup to see speed gains between one computer spread across all of mine versus each computer running parallel processes.
